review.title: A structured argumentation framework for detaching conditional obligations
review.abstract: We present a general formal argumentation system for dealing with the detachment of conditional obligations. Given a set of facts, constraints, and conditional obligations, we answer the question whether an unconditional obligation is detachable by considering reasons for and against its detachment. For the evaluation of arguments in favor of detaching obligations we use a Dung-style argumentation-theoretical semantics. We illustrate the modularity of the general framework by considering some extensions, and we compare the framework to some related approaches from the literature.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 6.00 339v 1 [cs.A I] We present a general formal argumentation system for dealing with the separation of conditional obligations. In view of a number of facts, limitations and conditional obligations, we answer the question whether an unconditional obligation is separable by considering reasons for and against its separation. To assess arguments for the separation of obligations, we use argument-theoretical semantics in the style of a dung. We illustrate the modularity of the general framework by taking into account some extensions and compare the framework with some related approaches from the literature. Keywords: formal reasoning, ASPIC +, conditional norms, conflicting norms, prioritized norms, factual detachment, deonic detachment.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: We take an argumentative perspective on the problem of the separation of conditional obligations in relation to a number of facts and limitations. We allow the construction of arguments whose deontic conclusions are candidates for separation. Next, we define a number of ways in which these arguments can attack each other, as if the conclusions of two arguments contradict each other. We borrow Dung's semantics [6] to evaluate arguments in relation to the attack relationships that exist between them. Conclusions of arguments that are evaluated positively are certainly separable within our framework. They can be interpreted as all-encompassing obligations - following Ross [28] - or spending obligations - following Makinson & van der Torre [18, 19]. The research of both authors was supported by a Sofja Kovalevskaya section award from the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, which is funded by the German Ministry of Education and Research. The argumentative approach defended in this paper is both natural and precise.

sections.heading: 4 Related work
sections.text: For reasons of space, we limit our discussion of related formalities to those of input / output logic (Section 4.1) and those based on formal frameworks of argumentation (Section 4.2). For an extended version of this article, a comparison with other related deontic systems, such as Nut's defective deontic logic [22, 21] and Horty's standards-based deontic logic [13, 10, 11, 15] remains.

sections.heading: 4.1 Input/output logic
sections.text: Like the limited input / output (I / O) logic of [19], the DAFs defined here are tools for separating conditional obligations in relation to a set of input / output (I / O) logic. Unlike most I / O logic, none of these DAFs is counterproductive if we allow conflict resolution by logical analysis in Section 3.1.1, as it allows the unrestricted derivation of more specific from less specific conditional obligations. sections.heading: 5 Outlook
sections.text: We presented a basic logic, DAF, for the replacement of conditional obligations based on dung-based semantics for formal argumentation. We expanded DAF to include mechanisms for conflict resolution and the anticipation of conflicts and violations, which, for the time being, serve mainly to illustrate the modularity of our framework. A detailed examination of, for example, different approaches to prioritized reasoning or different concepts of specifically based conflict resolution is reserved for an extended accompanying paper. We conclude by mentioning three challenges for future research: the first is to include approval declarations; the second is to increase the "logic" of 15 other solutions to this problem, e.g. in [33]. Our framework is enhanced by allowing nesting and the truth-functional combination of formulas OA, A, B or A. The third is to broaden our focus beyond substantiated extensions and examine how our framework behaves when subjected to different kinds of acceptable reasoning.
